material_source_passage: Cadmium oxide (CdO) is an important n-type semi-conductor with a direct band gap of 2.5 eV and an indirectband gap of 1.98 eV [12]. The difference in band gaporiginates from cadmium and oxygen vacancies andstrongly depends on the procedures of synthesis [13].Because of the large linear refractive index (n0 = 2.49),CdO is a promising candidate for optoelectronics applica-tions and can be used in the fabrication of solar cells,phototransistors, photodiodes, transparent electrodes, cat-alysts and gas sensors [14-17].

material_descriptor:
Single crystalline
Nanowires
synthesized at 150 °C by hydrothermal method
material_source_passage: Single-crystalline Cd(OH)<sub>2</sub> or CdO nanowires can be selectively synthesized at 150 °C by a simple hydrothermal method using aqueous Cd(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub> as precursor. The method is biosafe, and compared to the conventional oil-water surfactant approach, more environmental-benign. As revealed by the XRD results, CdO or Cd(OH)<sub>2</sub> nanowires can be generated in high purity by varying the time of synthesis. The results of FESEM and HRTEM analysis show that the CdO nanowires are formed in bundles. Over theCdO-nanowire bundles, photoluminescence at *517 nm attributable to near band-edge emission of CdO was recorded. Based on the experimental results, a possible growth mechanism of the products is proposed.

material_descriptor:
Single crystalline
Cubic phase
Nanowire bundles
synthesized at 150 °C for 24 h by hydrothermal method
Solids
JCPDS No. 78-0653
Average diameter around 40 nm
inter planar spacing of 111 plane is 0.273 nm
Nanostructures
material_source_passage: Single-crystalline Cd(OH)<sub>2</sub> or CdO nanowires can be selectively synthesized at 150 °C by a simple hydrothermal method using aqueous Cd(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub> as precursor. The method is biosafe, and compared to the conventional oil-water surfactant approach, more environmental-benign. As revealed by the XRD results, CdO or Cd(OH)<sub>2</sub> nanowires can be generated in high purity by varying the time of synthesis. The results of FESEM and HRTEM analysis show that the CdO nanowires are formed in bundles. Over theCdO-nanowire bundles, photoluminescence at *517 nm attributable to near band-edge emission of CdO was recorded. Based on the experimental results, a possible growth mechanism of the products is proposed.
property_source_passage: The X-ray diffraction (XRD) results of the samples collected at 10, 24, and 48 h are shown in Fig. 1. The peaks of the 24-h sample (Fig. 1b) are indexed to cubic phase of CdO with lattice constants of a = b = c = 0.4725 nm (JCPDS No. 78-0653).
